Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation2: A bride-to-be and her entourage arrive early, visibly anxious about the tight wedding schedule.
Story: I was halfway through curling a client’s hair when my phone buzzed for the third time. My stepmom’s messages flashed on the screen: “Don’t forget, we need you at the family brunch. It means a lot to your dad.” I glanced at the clock—just an hour before the big holiday celebration. But right then, the salon door swung open and the bride-to-be, along with her bridesmaids, rushed in, all nerves and chatter. They were early, and I could see the tension in their faces. As a hairdresser, I was expected to greet them warmly, calm their nerves, and make sure everything ran smoothly for their big day. But my mind kept drifting to my family, waiting for me to show up and be part of the celebration, to prove I belonged. My heart pounded as I tried to smile and welcome the bridal party, all the while feeling the weight of my family’s expectations pressing down on me. I stood there, scissors in hand, torn between the warmth of family and the duty to my clients, not knowing which world I’d have to disappoint.
